title: Quiz 1: Fundamentals of Nursing & Hygiene
description: Assessment on basic nursing skills including hand washing, patient positioning, bed making, bed baths, and pressure area care.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of hand washing in a clinical setting?

options.text: To reduce resident and transient microorganisms and prevent cross-infection

questions.explanation: The primary purpose is to remove/reduce dirt, resident and transient microorganisms, thereby preventing the transfer of microorganisms and controlling cross-infection.
questions.hint: Think about infection control and the two types of flora on the skin.

questions.question: Arrange the systematic way of performing procedures in the correct order:
questions.explanation: The standard sequence is: Hand washing -> Explain/Consent -> Assemble requirements -> Explain again -> Implementation -> Completion info -> Clearance -> Hand washing -> Documentation.
questions.hint: Start with hygiene, then communication, then preparation.

questions.question: Match the ethical principle with its correct definition:
questions.explanation: Beneficence = doing good; Non-maleficence = do no harm; Autonomy = freedom to choose; Justice = fairness.
questions.hint: Relate 'mal' to bad/harm and 'auto' to self.

questions.question: Which of the following are indications for hand washing? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Only when hands are visibly soiled

questions.explanation: Hand washing is indicated routinely before/after procedures, after contact with microorganisms/fluids, after removing gloves, and before leaving the facility. It is NOT limited to only when hands are visibly soiled.
questions.hint: Consider all moments where infection transmission risks exist.

questions.question: What is the recommended angle for a Semi-Fowlers position?
questions.explanation: Semi-Fowlers position involves tilting the bed at 15 to 30 degrees.
questions.hint: It is lower than the standard Fowlers position (45 degrees).

questions.question: Which position is described as: 'The client lies on the abdomen with the head turned to either side'?
questions.explanation: The Prone position involves lying on the abdomen. Supine is on the back, Lateral is on the side.
questions.hint: Think about the position often used to relieve pressure on the back.

questions.question: Match the patient position with its specific indication/rationale:

pairs.right: Reduce venous return to the heart

questions.explanation: Trendelenburg (head lower than feet) is for shock. Cardiac (sitting up supported) reduces venous return. Knee-chest raises the pelvis. Lateral helps drainage.
questions.hint: Connect 'Cardiac' to heart function and 'Trendelenburg' to blood flow to the brain.

questions.question: Which of the following are general rules of bed making? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Always ensure you miter all corners
Place soiled linen on the floor temporarily
Bottom sheet right side faces down

questions.explanation: Rules include: Never flip linen (spreads dust), never cover face, miter corners, never place linen on the floor. Bottom sheet right side should face UP (smooth side against patient).
questions.hint: Focus on infection control and patient comfort.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for making an occupied bed (Initial steps):

items.text: Loosen linen from head to foot
Fan fold dirty linen to the center
Place clean linen on the empty side

questions.explanation: First hygiene, then loosen old linen, turn patient to expose half the bed, roll dirty linen in, place clean linen.
questions.hint: You must prepare the bed before moving the patient.

questions.question: During a bed bath, the water temperature should be mixed to approximately ___BLANK___ degrees centigrade.
questions.explanation: Water should be mixed to approximately 37 degrees centigrade (body temperature) to prevent injury and enhance comfort.
questions.hint: Think of normal body temperature.

questions.question: When performing a bed bath, which part of the body should be washed first?
questions.explanation: The face is washed first with plain water, starting with the furthest eye, as it is the cleanest area.
questions.hint: We wash from cleanest to dirtiest.

questions.question: When washing the eyes during a bed bath, you should wipe from the outer canthus to the inner canthus.
questions.explanation: You should wipe from the inner canthus (inside) to the outer canthus (outside) to prevent sweeping debris into the nasolacrimal duct.
questions.hint: Think about the direction of drainage.

questions.question: Which of the following patients are at high risk for developing pressure sores? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Risk factors include immobility (paralysis, unconsciousness), moisture (incontinence), and nutritional status (obese/emaciated). Ambulatory patients are at lower risk.
questions.hint: Consider factors that increase pressure or reduce skin resistance.

questions.question: What is the rationale for soaping hands and massaging pressure points during pressure area care?

options.text: To relieve pressure and stimulate circulation

questions.explanation: Massage helps to stimulate blood circulation and relieve pressure on bony prominences.
questions.hint: Think about blood flow.

questions.question: When performing hand washing, you should keep hands and forearms in the UP position (elbows bent) if washing BEFORE a procedure.
questions.explanation: Before a procedure, water should flow from fingertips (cleanest) to elbows (least clean). After a procedure, hands should be down to rinse from wrists to fingers.
questions.hint: Consider where the water should drain to avoid contaminating clean areas.

questions.question: Which action is critical when evaluating the outcome of pressure area care?

options.text: Inspecting the skin for signs of loss of integrity

questions.explanation: Evaluation involves inspecting the condition of the skin to detect redness, blisters, or breaks in integrity.
questions.hint: Focus on the specific goal of the procedure.

questions.question: During bed making, you should never ___BLANK___ the linen as it spreads dust and microorganisms.
questions.explanation: Flipping or shaking linen disperses dust and pathogens into the air.
questions.hint: A common action to straighten sheets that should be avoided.

questions.question: Order the steps for a bed bath procedure after preparation:
questions.explanation: Sequence: Face -> Arms -> Chest/Abdomen -> Legs/Feet -> Genitalia (change water) -> Back.
questions.hint: Head to toe, generally, but back is often done last when turning.

questions.question: What is the definition of 'Non-maleficence' in nursing ethics?
questions.explanation: Non-maleficence specifically means the obligation to not inflict harm on others.
questions.hint: Mal = Bad/Harm.

questions.question: What position is used to reduce venous return to the heart?
questions.explanation: The Cardiac position (sitting up) uses gravity to reduce venous return, easing the workload on the heart.
questions.hint: Named after the organ it protects.
